awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Hybrid Multiterminal DC Grids for Renewable Energy Integration
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, a novel Hybrid multiterminal DC (MTDC) grid technology is proposed that can be a potential game-changer in the integration of renewable energy, particularly wind energy from both the offshore and onshore locations. Voltage Source Converter (VSC)-based high voltage DC (HVDC) is preferred over the Line Commutated Converter (LCC) technology in integrating offshore wind energy, whereas onshore wind farms with a few gigawatts of capacity rely on LCC-HVDC in transmitting power over long distances. Point-to-point HVDC links, i.e. HVDC transmission systems with only two converter stations and a DC transmission line that connect wind farms to the AC grid can suffer from issues including curtailment of wind power, poor reliability, and instability of the AC-DC system following huge loss of infeed due to a single-point failure. To address these issues, a Hybrid MTDC grid with multiple LCC and VSC stations that will act as the backbone of the power transmission corridor for evacuating wind energy into the surrounding AC grids is proposed. Although much research attention has been focused on the VSC-based MTDC grid in the recent past, hardly any literature exists on the proposed Hybrid MTDC grid that addresses integration issues of onshore wind farms with LCC-HVDC. For example, fundamental insight is yet to be developed to comprehend the control interactions that determine the frequency in such systems where wind farms are connected to an LCC-HVDC terminal in a "weak" AC grid. Moreover, there are complex operational challenges in such grids like power sharing issues following converter outage and problems due to the MTDC grid acting as a firewall and, thereby, decoupling the frequency support that is naturally available in traditional AC systems. To address these challenges, transformative ideas of system modeling, autonomous power sharing control, and frequency support strategy in Hybrid MTDC grids have been proposed that will substantially increase renewable penetration without compromising system reliability. In absence of any school in the nation that offers courses on HVDC and without a US manufacturer, this project is expected to contribute to the US efforts in this field. Graduate students working on this project will visit the Manitoba HVDC Research Center on a bi-annual basis to gain international research exposure. This program will promote teaching, training and learning of HVDC in the graduate program and renewable energy integration in the undergraduate program. To cultivate interest of K-12 students in power and energy systems, this project will conduct two STEM workshops in the West Fargo School district and a summer camp at NDSU, each year in coordination with the NDSU Engineering Outreach Office.

This project will develop a transformative approach that will establish a novel dynamic modeling philosophy in a frequency-dependent synchronous framework for Hybrid MTDC grids that interconnect inverter-interfaced offshore and onshore wind farms to the surrounding AC systems. Using this framework, a fundamental insight on the interaction among the weak AC system with low inertia and the controls of the LCC-HVDC terminal and the wind farm will be developed through an eigenvalue sensitivity-based approach. A novel adaptive autonomous control strategy and a novel emulative frequency support scheme of the surrounding AC systems from the offshore and onshore wind farms will also be pursued in the project.

Title: CAREER: Hybrid Multiterminal DC Grids for Renewable Energy Integration (ECCS 1656983) https://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1656983&HistoricalAwards=false   

Project Outcome Report

Background: Renewable energy, especially wind energy integration to the existing power grid poses many challenges. Onshore wind energy potential in the US is typically located far away from the load centers (e.g., cities). This requires long-distance transmission where high voltage dc (HVDC) is more beneficial compared to the ac option. Similarly, for deep sea offshore wind, HVDC is the sole option for cable transmission. However, integration of offshore and onshore wind energy in a continental scale in a reliable manner demands a multiterminal HVDC (MTDC) system that can reroute power, if one energy source is lost. The project aimed to provide solutions to multiple critical issues facing the operation of MTDC grids and surrounding ac systems due to loss of generation and converter loss, among others.

Technical Outcome: This project produced the following significant results 

  1. We established a new ratio-based frequency support mechanism among asynchronous ac grids through the MTDC grid. The provision of such frequency support is "selective" in nature, i.e., a converter station may opt out from providing frequency support. This can help create a market mechanism in future. We proposed an analytical approach for the design of inertial and primary frequency droop coefficients to maintain such ratios.
  2. We analytically established a region of stability in the inertial and primary frequency droop coefficient space and derived a subset of that region where both stability and ratio-based performance are guaranteed.
  3. Impact of progressively reducing inertia and effective short circuit ratio on the frequency dynamics of a weak grid where a type 3 wind farm is interfaced with a line commutated converter based HVDC is analyzed. In addition, the effect of HVDC inverter dynamics on the rectifier-side ac system is analyzed.
  4. A new hybrid HVDC converter topology with capacitor commutated converter (CCC) and voltage source converter (VSC) is proposed and their control coordination is established for weak grids. Secondary frequency support through such control coordination is also developed.
  5. A stability-constrained adaptive droop control in MTDC systems is proposed, which applies a trajectory sensitivity-based approach.
  6. To damp interarea oscillations, a robust multi-input multi-output supplementary controller is proposed for MTDC systems embedded in ac grids. The key idea to achieve robustness lies in explicitly modeling the MTDC current injection as disturbances using an H∞ mixed-sensitivity formulation in the linear matrix inequality framework.


Products: The project produced 15 journal papers (14 published, 1 under review at the time of writing this report), 6 conference proceedings, 1 monograph, 3 Ph.D. dissertations, and 1 MS Thesis. The papers can be freely accessed from the PI's website https://sites.psu.edu/nilanjan/publications/ .

Broader Impacts: The project will help in renewable energy integration and in turn meet climate change goals. In absence of many schools in the nation that offer courses on HVDC, this project is expected to contribute to the US efforts in this field. As part of integrative research and education, the PI taught a new module in EE488 Power Systems Analysis course every Spring titled "Wind and HVDC." Introductory concepts were presented based on the topic of research in this project. To that end, the students were taught from the first chapter of the book (available as e-book in PSU library) "Integrating Wind Energy to Weak Power Grids using High Voltage Direct Current Technology," Springer, ISBN:  978-3-030-03409-2, 241 pages, Jan. 2019. This book was published from research in this project.  In addition to the technical impact, as part of the outreach initiatives, the PI participated in 3 APOGEE summer camps during the project. APOGEE stands for Anything is POssible for Girls in Electrical Engineering, which is organized annually in the EE department, please see https://sites.psu.edu/apogee/apogee-2020/. It involves female 7th - 12th grade students. In 2020 and 2021, that camps were held virtually due to Covid-19 pandemic. The PI is happy to report that in 2022, he was able to participate in an in-person camp. The PI offered summer internship positions to 2 UG students every summer since the beginning of the project. The students worked on wind energy integration and HVDC-related projects and submitted final reports.
